The  Project,  developed  as  a  sector  loan  under  the  overall 
framework  of  the  Government  of  Pakistan's  poverty  reduction 
strategy  outlined  in  its  10-Year  Perspective  Development  Plan 
2001-2011,  will  provide  water  supply  and  sanitation  (WSS) 
facilities to about 2,500 rural communities in Punjab Province that 
have  brackish  groundwater  or  where  water  is  scarce  and  rainfall 
seasonal. It will also facilitate building the institutional capacity of 
newly  established  local  government  institutions  and  improving 
communities’  health  and  hygiene.  The  Project  includes  a  social 
uplift  and  poverty  eradication  program,  which  will  address  core 
poverty  issues  by  providing  income-generating  opportunities  to 
communities  together  with  the  education  benefits  linked  with  the 
provision of WSS facilities. 
 
It follows the successful implementation of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB)-assisted phase I project1 which successfully achieved 
its  development  objectives  particularly,  poverty  reduction,  gender 
and development, and environmental improvement.  
 

Punjab  is  the  country’s  largest  province  with  a  population  of 
approximately  84  million,  or  around  62%  of  the  country’s  total  of 
135  million.  About  60%  of  the  Punjab's  population  live  in  rural 
settlements,  and  36%  are  classified  as  poor.  The  overall  water 
supply  coverage  in  rural  Punjab  is  53%;  about  half  of  that  is 
provided by piped systems and the rest through community hand 
pumps.  The  remaining  47%  of  households  rely  on  often  distantly 
located sources of unsafe water, such as uncovered wells, rivers, 
and rain-fed or canal-fed ponds.  Similarly, only about 27% of the 
rural  population  has  access  to  sanitation  facilities  in  the  form  of 
household latrines.  About half of the villages are located in areas 
of brackish, polluted, or scarce water.

2. 
The Government is concerned about the low levels of social services, particularly in rural 
areas,  and  believes  that  greater  investment  in  basic  social  services  will  accelerate  gains  in 
productivity,  reduce  poverty,  and  promote  smaller,  healthier,  and  better  educated  families. 
Nationally,  the Government  has identified low water supply and sanitation coverage as one of 
the  major  issues  confronting  the  water  supply  and  sanitation  (WSS)  sector  in  Pakistan1.  At 
present,  the  overall  water  supply  coverage  in  Pakistan  is  63%  and  sanitation  39%  of  the  total 
population.   
 
3. 
Punjab  is  the  most  heavily  populated  province  of  Pakistan.  Despite  its  apparently 
affluent agricultural economy, the social indicators of Punjab compare poorly with those of most 
other provinces in the country. In fiscal year (FY) 1999, 33% of Punjab's population was poor, 
and in rural Punjab it was 36% compared with 29% in FY932.  During 1998/99 infant mortality in 
Punjab was 95 per 1,000 live births, against 89 for the country as a whole. At present, overall 
water supply coverage in rural Punjab is 53%; about half of that is provided by piped systems  
and the  rest  through  community hand pumps. The remaining 47% of households have to rely 
on  often  distantly  located  sources  of  unsafe  water-uncovered  wells,  rivers,  and  rain-fed/canal-
fed ponds - generally transported by women and children. These groups suffer significantly from 
waterborne diseases due to the use of water unfit for human consumption, and the cost of heath 
care  due  to  illness  is  high.  Similarly,  only  about  27%  of  the  rural  population  have  access  to 
sanitation facilities in the form of household latrines. The remaining population defecate in open 
areas,  a  situation  that  is  particularly  difficult  for  females,  as  by  custom  they  can  only  use  the 
fields  either  before  sunrise  or  after  sunset.  The  idea  of  health  benefits  being  associated  with 
good  hygiene  practices  needs  strengthening  if  the  health  of  rural  communities  is  to  improve. 
Drainage in rural areas is very poor and maintenance of existing drains is commonly neglected, 
which results in health hazards such as insect infestations and an environmental hazard such 
as unpleasant odors.   
 
 
4. 
While  some  aid-/NGO-assisted  projects  are  addressing  the  WSS  problems  of  smaller

inefficient WSS sector to an efficient community-run system.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

Objectives  

 
A. 
 
The  overall  goal  of  the  Project  is  to  reduce  poverty,  and  improve  the  living  conditions 
16. 
and  quality  of  life  of  the  communities  in  rural  settlements  in  Punjab  Province  where  water  is  
scarce  and  groundwater  is  brackish.    The  project  seeks  to:  (i)  extend  -  through  a  community 
based,  demand-driven  approach  -  water  supply,  drainage,  and  sanitation  coverage  to  poor 
village communities that do not have access to organized water supply and are located in the 
brackish  and  barani  areas  of  Punjab;  (ii)  strengthen  newly  constituted  TMAs  and  build  their 
capacity  to  organize  community-based  water  supply  and  drainage  schemes  and  improve 
related management functions; (iii) implement a hygiene education program including assisting 
selected  beneficiaries  in  the  project  tehsils  construct  household  latrines  through  a  revolving 
fund;  and  (iv)  implement  a  social  uplift  and  poverty  eradication  (SUPER)  program  aimed  at 
using the time saved in fetching water in more productive and livelihood activities, particularly 
for  women,  through  a  microcredit  system,  and  constructing  additional  classrooms  in  schools 
where  enrollment  has  increased  because  children  were  released  from  the  chore  of  fetching 
water.   
 
17. 
The Project intends to use a community-based approach to extend WSS facilities to 54 
tehsils  in  26  districts  of  Punjab,  which  are  facing  water  scarcity  and  saline  groundwater

comprising  about  91%  of  the  total  population  in  brakish/barani  areas,  will  receive  priority. 
However,  any  village  located  in  the  above  tehsils  and/or  other  tehsils  with  smaller  population 
would  also  be  considered  if  the  subproject  is  technically  viable  and  communities  accept  O&M 
responsibilities as per subproject selection criteria. Construction of about 500 new subprojects 
and  rehabilitation  of  about  250  need-based  inoperative  subprojects  (implemented  by  PHED, 
prior to the phase I project) will be included in the Project. A population of about 2.3 million will 
be covered.

65. 
The main project beneficiaries are women and girls who used to spend 2-5 hours daily in 
fetching  water  from  considerable  distance.  The  availability  of  water  on  their  doorstep  will  not 
only save their time, but also improve the quality of life due to improved hygienic conditions. The 
women will be relieved from the stress and discomfort of hauling water, specially during illness 
and extreme weathers, and they will have additional time for rest and leisure activities. They will 
be  able  to  divert  their  time  and  energy  to  more  productive  social  and  economic  activities, 
including better child and house care, farm production activities including tending livestock and 
poultry,  making  handicrafts  and  artifacts,  etc.  The  microcredit  component  of  the  Project  will 
enable  the  communities,  particularly  women,  to  pursue  income-generating  activities.  The  girls, 
who share the responsibility for water collection, will now be enrolled in schools. In the phase I 
project, school enrollment mainly of girls doubled in several villages.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 

 
1. 
This  Appendix  presents  the  detailed  economic  justification  for  community-operated 
small-scale  water  supply  and  sanitation  investment  in  the  saline  groundwater  areas  of  Punjab 
province.  Economic  and  financial  analyses  of  the  proposed  subprojects  were  prepared  in 
accordance  with the Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB's)  Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis 
of Projects, and the Handbook for the Economic Analysis of Water Supply Projects. Economic 
analysis  carried  out  on  10  typical  representative  water  supply  and  sanitation  schemes.  Six  
schemes  represent  pumping  schemes,  and  two  each  represent  gravity-based  schemes,  and 
rehabilitation schemes. The Project envisages construction of 750 schemes - 500 new pumping 
and  gravity-based  schemes  and  250  rehabilitation  schemes.  As  this  is  an  indicative 
apportionment,  the  actual  configuration  will  depend  on  the  demand  by  the  communities  for 
various  types  and  size  of  schemes.  Nonetheless,  based  on  the  most  likely  configuration,  the 
economic analysis has been carried out for (i) all the 10 schemes, and (ii) for the Project as a 
whole. The analysis includes estimation of the economic internal rate of return (EIRR), average 
incremental financial cost (AIFC), average incremental economic cost (AIEC), switching values, 
and poverty impact ratio (PIR).  The assumptions used in the analysis are in Section B. 
 
2. 
As  per  Government  policy,  only  those  communities  that  would  undertake  responsibility 
for  the  full  cost  of  operating  and  maintaining  the  schemes  will  qualify  for  the  Project.  Due  to 
limited availability of fresh water from alternate sources, the schemes under this Project will be 
designed  mainly  to  replace  the  existing  water  availability  with  safe  water,  with  some  provision 
for incremental water deliveries, arising from both increase in demand due to population growth 
and induced water demand. For such schemes, the relevant per household tariff is based on the 
actual expenditure incurred on operation and maintenance (O&M) of the scheme. There will be 
no metering, and the water supply will be rationed at fixed delivery hours for each household. 
There  will  not  be  any  quantity-based  progressive  tariff  structure,  and  each  household  will  be 
charged a fixed monthly tariff.

the capacity to invest in the infrastructure. Moreover, most of them are in small settlements with

capacity  and  are  willing  to  pay  for  the  O&M  cost  of  the  schemes.  In  most  communities,  the 
beneficiaries have shown their inclination to contribute a modest share of the capital cost in kind 
and in cash.

3. 

Project Benefits 

5. 
The proposed project will benefit an estimated population of about 2.3 million, increasing 
to  about  3.2  million  in  20  years.  The  main  benefit  is  the  economic  value  of  the  time  saved  by 
women  and  diverted  to  activities  that  will  contribute  to  the  socioeconomic  well-being  of  the 
household.  The  experience  from  the  phase  I  project  suggests  that  the  resultant  time  saving 
significantly  reduces  the  stress  on  women  and  girls.  With  water  supply  on  the  door-step, 
women’s  contribution  to  farm-related  activities,  tending  live  stock,  and  other  off-farm  income- 
generating  activities  has  considerably  increased.  Moreover,  women  have  more  time  for 
household  chorus  and  better  child  care.  Girls  who  used  to  share  the  burden  of  fetching  water 
are now able to attend school regularly.

6. 
In  addition,  there  are  significant  nonquantifiable  benefits,  especially  health-related 
benefits. Access to clean water has significantly reduced the incidence of waterborne diseases 
and  other  illnesses,  and  the  resultant  productivity  loss  due  to  absenteeism  from  work.  These 
benefits  are  difficult  to  quantify  and  have  been  excluded  in  estimating  the  EIRR.  Similarly, 
benefits, such as elimination of stagnant ponds that served as breeding places for mosquitoes, 
also have not been accounted for in the economic analysis. 
 
The  economic  analysis  is  based  on  the  traditional  with-  and  without-project  approach. 
7. 
The main benefits that have been quantified are value of time saved in collecting water; saved 
vendor cost; and value of capital and O&M cost saved. The last two represent private cost that 
some households incurred in maintaining partial supplies from existing sources.   
 
8. 
The value of time saved in collecting water is estimated as the value of the average time 
spent  by  women  in  collecting/fetching  water.  For  collecting/fetching  water,  women  on  average 
spend 3 hours a day. The normal wage for women is about PRs60 per day. Assuming 50% of 
the available time is used in productive employment, and applying a shadow wage rate of 0.7, 
the value of time saved in a year is estimated as PRs2,874.  
 
9. 
The  benefits  also  take  into  account  the  cost  that  households  in  the  without-project 
situation would have incurred. This includes savings from capital and O&M cost of the motorized 
or hand pumps.
